title: .NET Team Lead & Solution Architect Interview Quiz
titleEn: .NET Team Lead & Solution Architect Interview Quiz
description: A practice test with multiple-choice and true/false questions covering .NET leadership, architecture, cloud, design patterns, DevOps, SharePoint, Power Platform and enterprise engineering

questions.text: Which SPFx base class controls lifecycle of a client-side web part?
questions.explanation: The `BaseClientSideWebPart` class is the entry point for all client-side web parts in SPFx. It provides essential methods like `onInit()` for setup, `render()` to display the UI, and `onDispose()` for cleanup, managing the complete lifecycle of the web part on a SharePoint page.

questions.text: Which protocol is used by gRPC for high-performance RPC communication?
questions.explanation: gRPC leverages HTTP/2 for its performance benefits like multiplexing and server push. It uses Protocol Buffers (Protobuf) as its interface definition language and for serializing structured data, which is more efficient and compact than text-based formats like JSON.

questions.text: What is the command to create a new ASP.NET Core Web API project?
questions.explanation: The `dotnet new webapi` command uses the .NET CLI to create a new project based on the ASP.NET Core Web API template. This provides a basic structure with controllers, a `Program.cs` file, and `launchSettings.json` to get started quickly.

questions.text: Which logging abstraction is built into ASP.NET Core?
questions.explanation: ASP.NET Core includes a built-in logging framework with the `ILogger<T>` interface as its primary abstraction. This allows developers to write log messages without being tied to a specific logging provider (like Serilog, NLog, or the console logger), which can be configured in `Program.cs`.

questions.text: Which Azure service is most commonly used for hosting containerized .NET microservices?
questions.explanation: Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS) is a managed container orchestration service. It simplifies deploying, managing, and scaling containerized applications using Kubernetes, making it the standard choice for complex microservices architectures on Azure.

questions.text: Which HTTP method should be used when updating a resource partially?
questions.explanation: According to HTTP semantics, `PUT` is used to completely replace a resource with a new representation. `PATCH` is used to apply a partial modification to a resource, meaning you only send the fields that need to be changed.

questions.text: Which approach reduces downtime by switching traffic between two identical environments?
questions.explanation: Blue-Green deployment involves running two identical production environments ('Blue' and 'Green'). At any time, only one of them is live. To deploy a new version, you deploy to the inactive environment, test it, and then switch the router to send all traffic to the new version, allowing for zero-downtime deployments.

questions.text: Which authentication flow is recommended for server-to-server (daemon) apps in Azure AD?
questions.explanation: The Client Credentials grant flow is used when an application needs to access resources using its own identity, without a user being present. This is ideal for daemon services, background jobs, or server-to-server APIs where the application authenticates with its client ID and secret.

questions.text: Which monitoring technique captures end-to-end request flow across services?
questions.explanation: Distributed tracing is a method used to profile and monitor applications, especially those built using a microservices architecture. It helps pinpoint where failures occur and what causes poor performance by assigning a unique ID to a request and tracking its journey across multiple services.

questions.text: Which DevOps practice aims to keep codebase always in a releasable state by integrating changes frequently?
questions.explanation: Continuous Integration (CI) is a DevOps practice where developers frequently merge their code changes into a central repository, after which automated builds and tests are run. This helps to find and address bugs quicker, improve software quality, and reduce the time it takes to validate and release new software updates.

questions.text: Which Azure service provides serverless event-driven compute for short-running tasks?
questions.explanation: Azure Functions is a serverless compute service that lets you run event-triggered code without having to explicitly provision or manage infrastructure. It's ideal for short-running, stateless tasks like processing queue messages, responding to HTTP triggers, or running on a schedule.

questions.text: Which EF Core feature helps reduce round trips by retrieving related entities in a single query?
questions.explanation: Eager loading is the process whereby a query for one type of entity also loads related entities as part of the query. In EF Core, this is achieved using the `Include()` method. It results in a single, more complex query to the database but avoids subsequent round trips (the N+1 problem).

questions.text: Which tool is used to perform static code analysis and track code quality?
questions.explanation: SonarQube is an open-source platform for continuous inspection of code quality. It performs static code analysis to detect bugs, code smells, and security vulnerabilities in over 20 programming languages, providing reports and quality gates for CI/CD pipelines.

questions.text: Which message delivery semantic attempts to guarantee a message is processed only once?
questions.explanation: Exactly-once is the strongest delivery guarantee, ensuring that a message is delivered and processed only once, even in the event of failures. This is complex to achieve and often involves idempotent consumers and transactional processing. At-least-once is more common.

questions.text: Which pattern separates read and write models to improve scalability?
questions.explanation: Command Query Responsibility Segregation (CQRS) is an architectural pattern that separates the models for reading data (Queries) from the models for updating data (Commands). This allows the read and write workloads to be scaled and optimized independently.

questions.text: Which pattern helps manage failures by opening a circuit after repeated errors?
questions.explanation: The Circuit Breaker pattern is a resilience pattern that wraps a protected function call. It monitors for failures and, after a certain threshold, 'trips' the circuit to stop making calls to the failing service, allowing it to recover and preventing a cascading failure in the system.

questions.text: Which .NET runtime is cross-platform and optimized for high-performance server applications?
questions.explanation: .NET Core (now simply called .NET 5 and later) is the modern, open-source, and cross-platform successor to the .NET Framework. It is optimized for building high-performance, cloud-native server applications.

questions.text: Which Azure service provides distributed messaging with pub/sub semantics?
questions.explanation: Azure Service Bus Topics and Subscriptions provide a one-to-many form of communication in a publish/subscribe (pub/sub) pattern. A publisher sends a message to a topic, and one or more subscribers can receive a copy of the message, enabling decoupled, fan-out scenarios.

questions.text: Which SharePoint feature centralizes navigation across related sites?
questions.explanation: In modern SharePoint architecture, Hub Sites act as a connection point for multiple sites (both Team and Communication sites). They provide shared navigation, branding, and allow content to be rolled up and searched across all associated sites.

questions.text: Which Azure component provides identity and access management for apps?
questions.explanation: Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) is Microsoft's cloud-based identity and access management service. It is used to manage users, groups, and application identities, and provides authentication services like single sign-on (SSO) for thousands of SaaS applications, including Microsoft 365.

questions.text: Which Azure service is used for secrets, keys and certificate management?
questions.explanation: Azure Key Vault is a cloud service for securely storing and accessing secrets, such as API keys, passwords, or certificates. It provides centralized storage, hardware security modules (HSMs), and access policies to safeguard sensitive information.

questions.text: Which Azure service accelerates global content delivery via edge POPs?
questions.explanation: Azure Content Delivery Network (CDN) offers a global solution for rapidly delivering high-bandwidth content. It caches content at strategically placed physical nodes (Points of Presence or POPs) across the world to provide low-latency access to users.

questions.text: Which component in ASP.NET Core processes requests via a configured pipeline?
questions.explanation: In ASP.NET Core, middleware are software components that are assembled into an application pipeline to handle requests and responses. Each component can perform operations before and after the next component, forming a chain of responsibility.

questions.text: Which caching approach is best for storing session data in a distributed system?
questions.explanation: In a distributed system with multiple server instances, an in-process cache is not shared. A distributed cache, like Redis, provides a centralized, external store that all instances can access, ensuring data consistency and enabling scalable caching strategies.

questions.text: What design pattern is commonly used to decouple an interface from its implementation?
questions.explanation: Dependency Injection (DI) is a form of Inversion of Control (IoC) where an object receives its dependencies from an external source rather than creating them itself. This decouples components and makes the system more modular, flexible, and easier to test with mocks.

questions.text: Which provisioning engine is commonly used to automate modern SharePoint site provisioning?
questions.explanation: The SharePoint Patterns and Practices (PnP) Provisioning Engine is a framework that allows you to model a site's structure (lists, content types, pages, themes) in a template and apply it programmatically. It is the modern standard for automating site provisioning.

questions.text: Which storage is optimized for large binary files in Azure?
questions.explanation: Azure Blob Storage is Microsoft's object storage solution, optimized for storing massive amounts of unstructured data, such as text or binary data (documents, images, videos). It is highly scalable and cost-effective for this purpose.

questions.text: Which design principle stands for Open/Closed, Liskov, etc.?
questions.explanation: SOLID is a mnemonic acronym for five design principles intended to make software designs more understandable, flexible, and maintainable. The principles are: Single Responsibility, Open/Closed, Liskov Substitution, Interface Segregation, and Dependency Inversion.

questions.text: Which architectural style encourages splitting systems into independently deployable services?
questions.explanation: Microservices is an architectural style that structures an application as a collection of small, autonomous services, modeled around a business domain. Each service is self-contained and can be deployed and scaled independently.

questions.text: Which .NET collection provides O(1) average lookup by key?
questions.explanation: The `Dictionary<TKey, TValue>` class is implemented as a hash table. On average, this allows for retrieval, insertion, and deletion operations to be completed in constant time, O(1), making it highly efficient for key-based lookups.

questions.text: Which .NET feature allows a method to return a sequence of values over time, rather than all at once?
questions.explanation: Iterators using `yield return` enable deferred execution. The method generates values one at a time as they are requested by the consumer (e.g., in a `foreach` loop), which is highly memory-efficient for large sequences.

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of the 'Strangler Fig' pattern in software architecture?
answers: To incrementally migrate a legacy system by gradually replacing pieces of functionality with new applications and services.
To create a single, monolithic application from multiple smaller services.
To optimize database performance by 'strangling' slow queries.
To secure an application by wrapping it in a protective layer.
questions.correctAnswer: To incrementally migrate a legacy system by gradually replacing pieces of functionality with new applications and services.
questions.explanation: The Strangler Fig pattern is a low-risk method for modernizing legacy systems. New functionality is built around the old system, which is gradually 'strangled' until it can be decommissioned.

questions.text: In Power Automate, what is the role of a 'Connector'?
answers: To provide a bridge for Power Automate to communicate with another service's API (e.g., SharePoint, Twitter, SQL Server).
To connect two different flows together.
To define the trigger for a flow.
To store variables used within a flow.
questions.correctAnswer: To provide a bridge for Power Automate to communicate with another service's API (e.g., SharePoint, Twitter, SQL Server).
questions.explanation: Connectors are wrappers around APIs that allow different services to talk to each other. Power Automate has hundreds of pre-built connectors to enable integration with a wide range of Microsoft and third-party services.

questions.text: What is the primary difference between `Task.Run` and `Task.Factory.StartNew`?
answers: `Task.Run` is a modern, simplified API with safer defaults, while `StartNew` is a more complex, lower-level API.
`Task.Run` can only be used in `async` methods.
There is no difference; they are interchangeable.
questions.correctAnswer: `Task.Run` is a modern, simplified API with safer defaults, while `StartNew` is a more complex, lower-level API.
questions.explanation: `Task.Run` is the recommended way to queue work on the thread pool. It's essentially a shortcut for `Task.Factory.StartNew` with common, safe parameters. `StartNew` has complex options that can lead to unexpected behavior if not configured correctly.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the `[ProducesResponseType]` attribute in an ASP.NET Core controller action?
answers: To define the possible HTTP status codes and response types an action can return, for OpenAPI/Swagger documentation.
To restrict the action to only produce a specific response type.
To automatically serialize the response to JSON.
To measure the performance of the response.
questions.correctAnswer: To define the possible HTTP status codes and response types an action can return, for OpenAPI/Swagger documentation.
questions.explanation: This attribute enriches the metadata for an API endpoint, allowing tools like Swagger/Swashbuckle to generate more accurate and descriptive API documentation for consumers.

questions.text: In Azure DevOps, what is the difference between a 'Build Pipeline' and a 'Release Pipeline'?
answers: A Build Pipeline produces a deployable artifact; a Release Pipeline deploys that artifact to one or more environments.
A Build Pipeline is for .NET code; a Release Pipeline is for JavaScript.
They are the same thing, just with different names.
A Build Pipeline runs tests; a Release Pipeline does not.
questions.correctAnswer: A Build Pipeline produces a deployable artifact; a Release Pipeline deploys that artifact to one or more environments.
questions.explanation: The Build Pipeline (CI) compiles code and runs tests to create a versioned artifact. The Release Pipeline (CD) takes that artifact and manages its deployment through various stages (e.g., Dev, Staging, Prod), often including approvals and configuration changes.

questions.text: What is the 'N+1' query problem in the context of an ORM like Entity Framework?
answers: A performance issue where one initial query is executed, followed by N additional queries to fetch related data.
A security vulnerability where N+1 users can access the same data.
A database design where a table has N+1 foreign keys.
A feature that allows a query to be executed N+1 times for reliability.
questions.correctAnswer: A performance issue where one initial query is executed, followed by N additional queries to fetch related data.
questions.explanation: This often occurs with lazy loading. To fix it, you should use eager loading (with `Include()`) or explicit loading to fetch all the required data in a more efficient manner, typically with a single, more complex query.

questions.text: What is the primary goal of the 'Interface Segregation Principle' (ISP) in SOLID?
answers: To ensure that clients are not forced to depend on interfaces they do not use.
To create one large interface for all possible methods.
To segregate interfaces into separate files.
To make all interface methods virtual.
questions.correctAnswer: To ensure that clients are not forced to depend on interfaces they do not use.
questions.explanation: ISP advocates for creating smaller, more specific interfaces ('role interfaces') rather than large, general-purpose ones. This prevents classes from having to implement methods they don't need, leading to a more decoupled and maintainable design.

questions.text: In SharePoint, what is the difference between a 'Site Column' and a 'List Column'?
answers: A Site Column is reusable across multiple lists in a site collection; a List Column is specific to a single list.
Site Columns can only be of type 'Text', while List Columns can be any type.
List Columns are more performant than Site Columns.
There is no difference; the terms are interchangeable.
questions.correctAnswer: A Site Column is reusable across multiple lists in a site collection; a List Column is specific to a single list.
questions.explanation: Defining a column as a Site Column allows you to enforce consistency and reuse the same metadata definition across your site collection. A List Column is created directly on a list and can only be used there.

questions.text: What is the purpose of a 'correlation ID' in a microservices architecture?
answers: To track a single user request as it flows through multiple services, for logging and debugging.
To correlate database tables with service endpoints.
A unique ID for a specific service instance.
A security token used for authentication.
questions.correctAnswer: To track a single user request as it flows through multiple services, for logging and debugging.
questions.explanation: A correlation ID is passed in the headers of each service-to-service call. This allows you to aggregate all logs related to a single initial request, which is essential for distributed tracing and debugging in a complex system.

questions.text: Unit tests should not access real databases.
questions.explanation: Unit tests are meant to be fast and test a small piece of logic in isolation. Accessing a real database, network, or file system makes the test an 'integration test,' which is slower and more brittle. Dependencies should be mocked or stubbed in unit tests.

questions.text: SPFx web parts can run on classic SharePoint pages.
questions.explanation: SPFx web parts are designed to be backward compatible. You can add an SPFx web part to a classic web part page, providing a good migration path for gradually modernizing older SharePoint sites.

questions.text: Async/await improves throughput by increasing CPU utilization.
questions.explanation: Async/await improves application scalability and responsiveness, especially for I/O-bound operations (like web requests or database calls). It frees up the calling thread to do other work instead of blocking, which improves throughput, but it does not inherently increase raw CPU processing speed.

questions.text: Power Automate cannot update SharePoint document metadata.
questions.explanation: Power Automate has a rich SharePoint connector that includes actions to 'Update file properties' and 'Update item'. This allows you to easily build workflows that modify list item metadata or document library properties based on triggers or other logic.

questions.text: Entity Framework Core supports both LINQ and raw SQL queries.
questions.explanation: While LINQ to Entities is the primary way to query data, EF Core provides methods like `FromSqlRaw()` and `FromSqlInterpolated()` to execute raw SQL queries when you need to run a query that can't be expressed in LINQ or when you need to optimize a specific query.

questions.text: gRPC is generally faster than REST for internal service communication.
questions.explanation: For internal service-to-service communication, gRPC is often more performant than REST over JSON. This is because it uses the efficient Protocol Buffers (Protobuf) binary serialization format and leverages the capabilities of HTTP/2, such as multiplexing and streaming.

questions.text: Azure Functions can be triggered by a SharePoint Webhook.
questions.explanation: SharePoint webhooks can be configured to send a notification to a publicly accessible REST endpoint whenever a change occurs in a list. An Azure Function with an HTTP trigger is a perfect serverless candidate for receiving and processing these notifications.

questions.text: Structs in C# are reference types.
questions.explanation: Structs are value types, meaning their variables directly contain their data and are typically stored on the stack. Classes are reference types, where variables hold a reference to an object stored on the heap.

questions.text: Modern SharePoint promotes flat site architecture over deep subsite structures.
questions.explanation: The modern SharePoint architecture favors a 'flat' structure of many independent site collections. These sites are then associated with Hub Sites to provide shared navigation, branding, and search capabilities, offering more flexibility than the rigid hierarchy of classic subsites.

questions.text: JWT tokens must always be stored in local storage for security.
questions.explanation: Storing JWTs in local storage makes them accessible to any JavaScript running on the page, creating a significant Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vulnerability. Storing them in secure, HttpOnly cookies is a much safer alternative for web applications.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the Repository Pattern in .NET?
answers: To abstract data access logic and provide a central location for data operations
questions.correctAnswer: To abstract data access logic and provide a central location for data operations
questions.explanation: The Repository Pattern mediates between the domain and data mapping layers, acting like an in-memory collection of domain objects. It provides a cleaner architecture and makes the code more testable by abstracting the data access logic.

questions.text: Which Power Platform component allows creating custom business logic using visual designers?
questions.explanation: Power Automate (formerly Microsoft Flow) allows users to create automated workflows between applications and services. It provides visual designers for building business logic without extensive coding.

questions.text: In .NET, what is the difference between `IEnumerable<T>` and `IQueryable<T>`?
answers: `IQueryable<T>` supports query composition and deferred execution with expression trees, while `IEnumerable<T>` executes queries in-memory
`IQueryable<T>` can only be used with arrays
questions.correctAnswer: `IQueryable<T>` supports query composition and deferred execution with expression trees, while `IEnumerable<T>` executes queries in-memory
questions.explanation: `IQueryable<T>` is used for building database queries that execute on the server, while `IEnumerable<T>` brings data into memory first. Using `IQueryable` allows for more efficient queries with filtering/sorting done at the database level.

questions.text: What is the main benefit of using Azure Functions for .NET microservices?
answers: Serverless execution with automatic scaling and pay-per-execution pricing
It replaces the need for containers
questions.correctAnswer: Serverless execution with automatic scaling and pay-per-execution pricing
questions.explanation: Azure Functions provide a serverless compute service that automatically scales based on demand and charges only for the compute time used. This is ideal for event-driven microservices and can significantly reduce infrastructure management overhead.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the `IOptions<T>` pattern in ASP.NET Core?
answers: To provide strongly-typed access to configuration settings
questions.correctAnswer: To provide strongly-typed access to configuration settings
questions.explanation: The Options pattern uses classes to provide strongly-typed access to groups of related settings from configuration sources like appsettings.json. It supports dependency injection and makes configuration management more maintainable.

questions.text: In DevOps, what is 'Infrastructure as Code' (IaC)?
answers: Managing and provisioning infrastructure through machine-readable definition files
Writing application code that runs on servers
questions.correctAnswer: Managing and provisioning infrastructure through machine-readable definition files
questions.explanation: IaC treats infrastructure setup as code that can be versioned, tested, and deployed automatically. Tools like Terraform, ARM templates, and Bicep allow teams to define infrastructure declaratively, ensuring consistency and reproducibility.

questions.text: What is the Circuit Breaker pattern used for in microservices?
answers: To prevent cascading failures by stopping requests to a failing service
To break circular dependencies in code
questions.correctAnswer: To prevent cascading failures by stopping requests to a failing service
questions.explanation: The Circuit Breaker pattern monitors for failures and temporarily blocks requests to a failing service, giving it time to recover. This prevents the failure from spreading to other services in a distributed system.

questions.text: Which Azure service provides a managed message broker for reliable message delivery?
questions.explanation: Azure Service Bus is an enterprise message broker with message queues and publish-subscribe topics. It provides reliable message delivery, transaction support, and advanced features like message sessions and dead-lettering.

questions.text: What is the main purpose of using `async` and `await` in C#?
answers: To write asynchronous code that doesn't block threads while waiting for I/O operations
questions.correctAnswer: To write asynchronous code that doesn't block threads while waiting for I/O operations
questions.explanation: Async/await enables writing asynchronous code that looks synchronous. It prevents blocking threads during I/O operations, improving application scalability and responsiveness, especially in web applications.

questions.text: In SharePoint Online, what is the recommended approach for custom development?
answers: SharePoint Framework (SPFx) with client-side web parts
questions.correctAnswer: SharePoint Framework (SPFx) with client-side web parts
questions.explanation: SPFx is the modern development model for SharePoint Online. It uses client-side technologies (TypeScript, React, etc.) and is fully supported in modern SharePoint sites, providing a secure and performant way to extend SharePoint.

questions.text: What is the CQRS pattern in software architecture?
answers: Command Query Responsibility Segregation - separating read and write operations
questions.correctAnswer: Command Query Responsibility Segregation - separating read and write operations
questions.explanation: CQRS separates the model that reads data from the model that writes data. This allows for independent optimization, scaling, and security management of read and write operations, which is particularly useful in complex domains.

questions.text: Which .NET tool is used for analyzing code quality and finding potential issues?
questions.explanation: Roslyn-based code analyzers provide real-time code analysis in Visual Studio and during builds. They can detect potential bugs, style violations, and suggest improvements, helping maintain code quality across the team.

questions.text: What is the purpose of Azure API Management?
answers: To create a unified API gateway with security, throttling, and monitoring
questions.correctAnswer: To create a unified API gateway with security, throttling, and monitoring
questions.explanation: Azure API Management acts as a facade for backend services, providing features like authentication, rate limiting, caching, transformation, and analytics. It helps organizations publish, secure, and analyze their APIs.

questions.text: In .NET Core, what is middleware?
answers: Components that form the request processing pipeline
questions.correctAnswer: Components that form the request processing pipeline
questions.explanation: Middleware components are assembled into an application pipeline to handle requests and responses. Each component can perform operations before and after the next component in the pipeline, enabling cross-cutting concerns like authentication, logging, and error handling.

questions.text: What is the Saga pattern in microservices?
answers: A pattern for managing distributed transactions across multiple services
questions.correctAnswer: A pattern for managing distributed transactions across multiple services
questions.explanation: The Saga pattern manages data consistency across microservices by breaking a transaction into a series of local transactions. Each service performs its transaction and publishes events, with compensating transactions to roll back on failure.

questions.text: Which Azure service is best for hosting static web applications?
questions.explanation: Azure Static Web Apps is optimized for hosting static content (HTML, CSS, JavaScript) with global distribution via CDN. It includes built-in CI/CD from GitHub/Azure DevOps and can integrate with Azure Functions for serverless APIs.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the Unit of Work pattern?
answers: To maintain a list of objects affected by a transaction and coordinate writing changes
To split work into smaller units
questions.correctAnswer: To maintain a list of objects affected by a transaction and coordinate writing changes
questions.explanation: The Unit of Work pattern keeps track of all changes during a business transaction and coordinates the writing of changes to the database. Entity Framework's DbContext implements this pattern, ensuring consistency in database operations.

questions.text: In SharePoint, what is a Content Type?
answers: A reusable collection of metadata, workflows, and behaviors for a category of items
questions.correctAnswer: A reusable collection of metadata, workflows, and behaviors for a category of items
questions.explanation: Content Types define the attributes, workflows, and behaviors for a category of items or documents. They enable consistent handling of similar content across lists and libraries, promoting reuse and standardization.

questions.text: What is Azure DevOps Service Connection used for?
answers: To securely connect Azure DevOps pipelines to external services and Azure resources
To link source code repositories only
questions.correctAnswer: To securely connect Azure DevOps pipelines to external services and Azure resources
questions.explanation: Service Connections store credentials and configuration needed to access external services from pipelines. They support various authentication methods and can connect to Azure subscriptions, Docker registries, Kubernetes clusters, and more.

questions.text: What is the Outbox pattern in microservices?
answers: A pattern for reliably publishing events by storing them in the same transaction as business data
questions.correctAnswer: A pattern for reliably publishing events by storing them in the same transaction as business data
questions.explanation: The Outbox pattern ensures reliable event publishing by storing events in an 'outbox' table within the same database transaction as business data changes. A separate process then publishes these events, ensuring atomicity.

questions.text: What is Dependency Injection in .NET?
answers: A design pattern where objects receive their dependencies from external sources rather than creating them
A way to inject SQL queries
questions.correctAnswer: A design pattern where objects receive their dependencies from external sources rather than creating them
questions.explanation: Dependency Injection (DI) is a technique where a class receives its dependencies from external sources rather than creating them itself. .NET Core has built-in DI support that promotes loose coupling and testability.

questions.text: Which HTTP status code indicates a successful resource creation?
questions.explanation: HTTP 201 Created indicates that the request has been fulfilled and resulted in a new resource being created. The response should include a Location header with the URI of the newly created resource.

questions.text: What is the purpose of Azure Key Vault?
answers: To securely store and manage secrets, keys, and certificates
questions.correctAnswer: To securely store and manage secrets, keys, and certificates
questions.explanation: Azure Key Vault provides secure storage for cryptographic keys, secrets, and certificates. It includes access control, auditing, and integration with Azure services, helping organizations meet security and compliance requirements.

questions.text: What is the Bulkhead pattern in microservices?
answers: Isolating resources to prevent failures in one part from affecting others
questions.correctAnswer: Isolating resources to prevent failures in one part from affecting others
questions.explanation: The Bulkhead pattern partitions service instances and resources to isolate failures. Like compartments in a ship, if one section fails, it doesn't sink the entire system. This improves resilience in distributed systems.

questions.text: In .NET, what is the difference between `String` and `StringBuilder`?
answers: `String` is immutable; `StringBuilder` is mutable and more efficient for multiple concatenations
questions.correctAnswer: `String` is immutable; `StringBuilder` is mutable and more efficient for multiple concatenations
questions.explanation: Strings in .NET are immutable - each modification creates a new string object. StringBuilder is mutable and uses a buffer that can be modified without creating new objects, making it more efficient for repeated string manipulations.

questions.text: What is Azure Application Insights used for?
questions.explanation: Application Insights is an extensible Application Performance Management (APM) service. It monitors live applications, automatically detects performance anomalies, and includes analytics tools to diagnose issues and understand user behavior.

questions.text: What is the Retry pattern in distributed systems?
answers: Automatically retrying failed operations with exponential backoff
questions.correctAnswer: Automatically retrying failed operations with exponential backoff
questions.explanation: The Retry pattern handles transient failures by automatically retrying operations. It typically uses exponential backoff and jitter to avoid overwhelming the failing service, improving reliability in distributed systems.

questions.text: Which PowerShell command is used in SharePoint PnP to connect to a SharePoint site?
questions.explanation: Connect-PnPOnline is the PnP PowerShell command that establishes a connection to SharePoint Online or on-premises. It supports various authentication methods including credentials, app-only authentication, and MFA.

questions.text: What is the purpose of Health Checks in ASP.NET Core?
answers: To expose endpoints that report application and dependency health status
questions.correctAnswer: To expose endpoints that report application and dependency health status
questions.explanation: Health Checks provide endpoints that report the health of an app and its dependencies (databases, external services). They're used by load balancers and orchestrators to determine if an instance is ready to receive traffic.

questions.text: What is Event Sourcing in software architecture?
answers: Storing state changes as a sequence of events rather than just the current state
questions.correctAnswer: Storing state changes as a sequence of events rather than just the current state
questions.explanation: Event Sourcing persists the state of an entity as a sequence of state-changing events. This provides a complete audit trail, enables temporal queries, and allows rebuilding state at any point in time.

questions.text: Which Azure service provides managed Redis cache?
questions.explanation: Azure Cache for Redis provides a managed in-memory data store based on Redis. It offers high throughput and low latency for frequently accessed data, supporting caching, session storage, and pub/sub messaging patterns.

questions.text: What is the Anti-Corruption Layer pattern?
answers: A translation layer between different subsystems that don't share the same semantics
A security feature to prevent SQL injection
questions.correctAnswer: A translation layer between different subsystems that don't share the same semantics
questions.explanation: The Anti-Corruption Layer (ACL) pattern creates a facade or adapter between a modern subsystem and a legacy system. It prevents the legacy system's model from 'corrupting' the new system's domain model.

questions.text: In .NET, what is the Global Assembly Cache (GAC)?
answers: A machine-wide cache for shared .NET assemblies
questions.correctAnswer: A machine-wide cache for shared .NET assemblies
questions.explanation: The GAC is a machine-wide code cache for assemblies that need to be shared across multiple applications. It allows side-by-side versioning and is typically used for shared libraries and system components.

questions.text: What is Azure Cosmos DB best suited for?
answers: Globally distributed, multi-model database with low latency
questions.correctAnswer: Globally distributed, multi-model database with low latency
questions.explanation: Azure Cosmos DB is a globally distributed NoSQL database service that supports multiple data models (document, key-value, graph, column-family). It provides guaranteed single-digit millisecond latency and multiple consistency levels.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the Mediator pattern in .NET?
answers: To reduce coupling between objects by introducing a mediator object for communication
questions.correctAnswer: To reduce coupling between objects by introducing a mediator object for communication
questions.explanation: The Mediator pattern (implemented by libraries like MediatR) reduces direct dependencies between objects by having them communicate through a mediator. This promotes loose coupling and aligns well with CQRS implementations.

questions.text: Which SharePoint feature allows external users to access content?
questions.explanation: SharePoint's External Sharing feature allows organizations to share sites, documents, and folders with people outside the organization. It supports anonymous links, authenticated external users, and can be controlled at tenant, site, and item levels.

questions.text: What is the purpose of Docker containers in .NET development?
answers: To package applications with their dependencies for consistent deployment across environments
questions.correctAnswer: To package applications with their dependencies for consistent deployment across environments
questions.explanation: Docker containers package applications and their dependencies into isolated units that run consistently across different environments. This eliminates 'works on my machine' problems and simplifies deployment and scaling.

questions.text: What is Azure Service Fabric?
answers: A distributed systems platform for building microservices and containers
questions.correctAnswer: A distributed systems platform for building microservices and containers
questions.explanation: Azure Service Fabric is a platform for building and managing scalable and reliable microservices and containers. It handles deployment, scaling, load balancing, and failure recovery, allowing developers to focus on business logic.

questions.text: What is the purpose of `IHostedService` in .NET Core?
answers: To run background tasks in a hosted environment
questions.correctAnswer: To run background tasks in a hosted environment
questions.explanation: `IHostedService` allows running background tasks in ASP.NET Core applications. It provides `StartAsync` and `StopAsync` methods for managing long-running operations like message queue processing or scheduled tasks.

questions.text: What is the Backends for Frontends (BFF) pattern?
answers: Creating separate backend services optimized for specific frontend applications
questions.correctAnswer: Creating separate backend services optimized for specific frontend applications
questions.explanation: The BFF pattern involves creating separate backend services tailored to the needs of specific frontend applications (web, mobile, etc.). This allows each frontend to have an optimized API without compromising the needs of others.

questions.text: In ASP.NET Core, what is the purpose of Action Filters?
answers: To execute code before and after action methods execute
questions.correctAnswer: To execute code before and after action methods execute
questions.explanation: Action Filters allow running code before and after controller action methods. They're useful for cross-cutting concerns like logging, caching, authorization, and exception handling without repeating code in every action.

questions.text: What is Azure Front Door?
answers: A global load balancer and application delivery network with WAF capabilities
A physical entrance to Azure datacenters
questions.correctAnswer: A global load balancer and application delivery network with WAF capabilities
questions.explanation: Azure Front Door is a global, scalable entry point that uses Microsoft's global edge network. It provides load balancing, SSL offload, URL-based routing, and Web Application Firewall protection for web applications.

questions.text: What is the Specification pattern in domain-driven design?
answers: Encapsulating business rules in reusable, composable objects
questions.correctAnswer: Encapsulating business rules in reusable, composable objects
questions.explanation: The Specification pattern encapsulates business rules into composable objects that can be combined and reused. It's particularly useful for complex domain logic and query building while keeping the domain model clean.

questions.text: Which tool is commonly used for continuous integration in .NET projects?
answers: Azure DevOps Pipelines or GitHub Actions
questions.correctAnswer: Azure DevOps Pipelines or GitHub Actions
questions.explanation: Azure DevOps Pipelines and GitHub Actions are popular CI/CD platforms for .NET projects. They provide automated build, test, and deployment workflows with extensive integration with .NET tools and Azure services.

questions.text: What is the purpose of SignalR in .NET?
answers: To add real-time web functionality enabling server-to-client push
questions.correctAnswer: To add real-time web functionality enabling server-to-client push
questions.explanation: SignalR is a library that simplifies adding real-time web functionality. It enables the server to push content to connected clients instantly using WebSockets (with fallbacks), making it ideal for chat, dashboards, and notifications.

questions.text: What is Azure Logic Apps?
answers: A cloud service for creating automated workflows and integrations
questions.correctAnswer: A cloud service for creating automated workflows and integrations
questions.explanation: Azure Logic Apps enables building automated workflows that integrate apps, data, and services. It provides a visual designer and hundreds of connectors, making it easy to create enterprise integration and automation solutions.

questions.text: What is the Command pattern in software design?
answers: Encapsulating a request as an object, allowing parameterization and queuing
questions.correctAnswer: Encapsulating a request as an object, allowing parameterization and queuing
questions.explanation: The Command pattern encapsulates a request as an object, allowing you to parameterize clients with different requests, queue requests, and support undoable operations. It's the foundation of the CQRS pattern.

questions.text: In SharePoint development, what is a Feature?
answers: A packaged set of functionality that can be activated or deactivated
questions.correctAnswer: A packaged set of functionality that can be activated or deactivated
questions.explanation: A SharePoint Feature is a container for elements like web parts, lists, content types, and event receivers. Features can be scoped to different levels (farm, web application, site collection, site) and activated/deactivated as needed.

questions.text: What is the purpose of Azure Traffic Manager?
answers: DNS-based traffic routing to distribute traffic across global Azure regions
Managing network traffic within a single datacenter
questions.correctAnswer: DNS-based traffic routing to distribute traffic across global Azure regions
questions.explanation: Azure Traffic Manager uses DNS to direct client requests to the most appropriate service endpoint based on routing methods like priority, weighted, performance, or geographic. It provides high availability and responsiveness.

questions.text: What is Polly in .NET?
questions.explanation: Polly is a .NET library that provides patterns for handling transient faults. It offers retry, circuit breaker, timeout, bulkhead isolation, and fallback policies in a fluent API, making applications more resilient.

questions.text: What is the Decorator pattern in object-oriented design?
answers: Dynamically adding behavior to objects without modifying their code
questions.correctAnswer: Dynamically adding behavior to objects without modifying their code
questions.explanation: The Decorator pattern attaches additional responsibilities to an object dynamically. It provides a flexible alternative to subclassing for extending functionality, following the Open/Closed Principle.

questions.text: What is Azure Blob Storage primarily used for?
answers: Storing unstructured data like documents, images, and videos
questions.correctAnswer: Storing unstructured data like documents, images, and videos
questions.explanation: Azure Blob Storage is optimized for storing massive amounts of unstructured data. It supports different access tiers (hot, cool, archive) and is commonly used for backup, media storage, and data lakes.

questions.text: What is the Observer pattern used for?
answers: Defining a one-to-many dependency where observers are notified of state changes
questions.correctAnswer: Defining a one-to-many dependency where observers are notified of state changes
questions.explanation: The Observer pattern defines a subscription mechanism where multiple observers can be notified automatically when a subject's state changes. It's fundamental to event-driven programming and is implemented through events and delegates in .NET.

questions.text: In DevOps, what is a 'deployment slot' in Azure App Service?
answers: A separate instance for staging that can be swapped with production
questions.correctAnswer: A separate instance for staging that can be swapped with production
questions.explanation: Deployment slots are live apps with their own hostnames. You can deploy new versions to a staging slot, validate them, and then swap with production with zero downtime. This enables blue-green deployments.

questions.text: What is the Strategy pattern in software design?
answers: Defining a family of algorithms and making them interchangeable
questions.correctAnswer: Defining a family of algorithms and making them interchangeable
questions.explanation: The Strategy pattern defines a family of algorithms, encapsulates each one, and makes them interchangeable. It lets the algorithm vary independently from clients that use it, promoting flexibility and testability.

questions.text: What is Azure Durable Functions?
answers: An extension for writing stateful workflows in a serverless environment
questions.correctAnswer: An extension for writing stateful workflows in a serverless environment
questions.explanation: Durable Functions extends Azure Functions with stateful workflows. It enables function chaining, fan-out/fan-in, and long-running orchestrations while maintaining serverless benefits through automatic checkpointing and replay.

questions.text: What is the Factory pattern used for?
answers: Creating objects without specifying their exact classes
questions.correctAnswer: Creating objects without specifying their exact classes
questions.explanation: The Factory pattern provides an interface for creating objects, but lets subclasses decide which class to instantiate. It promotes loose coupling by eliminating the need to bind application-specific classes into the code.

questions.text: What is Power Apps?
answers: A low-code platform for building custom business applications
questions.correctAnswer: A low-code platform for building custom business applications
questions.explanation: Power Apps enables users to build custom apps with little or no code. It connects to various data sources, provides a drag-and-drop interface, and can create canvas apps, model-driven apps, or portals.

questions.text: What is the purpose of `ModelState` in ASP.NET Core MVC?
answers: To track validation errors and model binding results
questions.correctAnswer: To track validation errors and model binding results
questions.explanation: `ModelState` represents the state of model binding and validation. It contains errors from model binding and validation, allowing controllers to check `ModelState.IsValid` before processing requests.

questions.text: What is Azure Monitor?
answers: A comprehensive monitoring solution for collecting, analyzing, and acting on telemetry
questions.correctAnswer: A comprehensive monitoring solution for collecting, analyzing, and acting on telemetry
questions.explanation: Azure Monitor maximizes availability and performance by collecting, analyzing, and acting on telemetry from cloud and on-premises environments. It includes metrics, logs, alerts, and integration with Application Insights.

questions.text: What is the Adapter pattern in software design?
answers: Converting an interface into another interface that clients expect
questions.correctAnswer: Converting an interface into another interface that clients expect
questions.explanation: The Adapter pattern allows incompatible interfaces to work together. It acts as a bridge between two incompatible interfaces by wrapping an existing class with a new interface, enabling reuse of existing functionality.

questions.text: What is Azure SQL Database?
answers: A fully managed relational database service based on SQL Server
questions.correctAnswer: A fully managed relational database service based on SQL Server
questions.explanation: Azure SQL Database is a managed relational database service built on SQL Server engine. It provides automatic updates, scaling, backups, and high availability without the need to manage infrastructure.

questions.text: What is the Singleton pattern?
answers: Ensuring a class has only one instance with global access
questions.correctAnswer: Ensuring a class has only one instance with global access
questions.explanation: The Singleton pattern restricts instantiation of a class to one object and provides a global point of access. While useful, it should be used sparingly as it can create hidden dependencies and testing challenges.

questions.text: What is Blazor in .NET?
answers: A framework for building interactive web UIs using C# instead of JavaScript
questions.correctAnswer: A framework for building interactive web UIs using C# instead of JavaScript
questions.explanation: Blazor allows building interactive web applications using C# and .NET instead of JavaScript. It supports WebAssembly (client-side) and Server-side hosting models, enabling full-stack .NET development.

questions.text: What is the purpose of Azure Resource Manager (ARM) templates?
questions.explanation: ARM templates are JSON files that define infrastructure and configuration for Azure resources. They enable Infrastructure as Code, allowing consistent, repeatable deployments with version control and testing.

questions.text: What is the Template Method pattern?
answers: Defining a skeleton of an algorithm with steps that subclasses can override
questions.correctAnswer: Defining a skeleton of an algorithm with steps that subclasses can override
questions.explanation: The Template Method pattern defines the skeleton of an algorithm in a base class, letting subclasses override specific steps without changing the algorithm's structure. It promotes code reuse and enforces a workflow.

questions.text: What is Entity Framework Core?
questions.explanation: Entity Framework Core is a lightweight, cross-platform ORM that enables .NET developers to work with databases using .NET objects. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, and code-first or database-first approaches.

questions.text: What is Azure Container Registry?
answers: A managed Docker registry service for storing container images
questions.correctAnswer: A managed Docker registry service for storing container images
questions.explanation: Azure Container Registry stores and manages private Docker container images and artifacts. It integrates with AKS, Azure DevOps, and other services, supporting geo-replication and security scanning.

questions.text: What is the Proxy pattern used for?
answers: Providing a surrogate to control access to another object
questions.correctAnswer: Providing a surrogate to control access to another object
questions.explanation: The Proxy pattern provides a placeholder for another object to control access to it. It can add lazy initialization, access control, logging, or caching without changing the original object's code.

questions.text: What is the purpose of Background Services in .NET Core?
answers: To run long-running background tasks within an application
questions.correctAnswer: To run long-running background tasks within an application
questions.explanation: Background Services (implementing `BackgroundService` base class) enable running long-running operations in ASP.NET Core. They're useful for scheduled tasks, message processing, and continuous monitoring operations.

questions.text: .NET Core is cross-platform and can run on Windows, Linux, and macOS.
questions.explanation: .NET Core (now .NET 5+) is a cross-platform, open-source framework that runs on Windows, Linux, and macOS, enabling developers to build and deploy applications across different operating systems.

questions.text: Microservices should share a single database to ensure data consistency.
questions.explanation: Microservices should follow database-per-service pattern where each service owns its data. This ensures loose coupling and allows services to evolve independently. Consistency is managed through eventual consistency patterns.

questions.text: Azure Functions can only be triggered by HTTP requests.
questions.explanation: Azure Functions supports numerous triggers including HTTP, timers, Azure Storage queues and blobs, Service Bus, Event Grid, Cosmos DB changes, and more, making them versatile for various scenarios.

questions.text: In SOLID principles, the 'D' stands for Dependency Inversion.
questions.explanation: The 'D' in SOLID stands for Dependency Inversion Principle, which states that high-level modules should not depend on low-level modules; both should depend on abstractions.

questions.text: SharePoint Framework (SPFx) solutions must be deployed to the SharePoint app catalog.
questions.explanation: SPFx solutions are packaged as .sppkg files that must be uploaded to the tenant or site collection app catalog before they can be added to SharePoint sites.

questions.text: Async methods in C# must always return Task or Task<T>.
questions.explanation: While most async methods return Task or Task<T>, they can also return void (for event handlers), ValueTask<T> (for performance), or custom awaitable types. However, async void should generally be avoided except for event handlers.

questions.text: Azure DevOps supports both Git and TFVC for source control.
questions.explanation: Azure DevOps Repos supports both Git (distributed version control) and Team Foundation Version Control (TFVC, centralized version control), allowing teams to choose based on their preferences.

questions.text: The Repository pattern eliminates the need for Entity Framework.
questions.explanation: The Repository pattern is an abstraction layer over data access, often implemented using Entity Framework. It doesn't replace EF but provides an additional layer of abstraction for better testability and maintainability.

questions.text: LINQ queries are always executed immediately when they are defined.
questions.explanation: LINQ queries use deferred execution by default - they're not executed until the results are enumerated (e.g., in a foreach loop or calling ToList()). This allows for query composition and optimization.

questions.text: Azure App Service can automatically scale based on metrics like CPU usage.
questions.explanation: Azure App Service supports autoscaling based on various metrics including CPU percentage, memory percentage, HTTP queue length, and custom metrics. It can scale out/in based on rules and schedules.

questions.text: In Domain-Driven Design, the domain layer should have dependencies on infrastructure concerns.
questions.explanation: In DDD, the domain layer should be free of infrastructure dependencies. Dependencies should point inward toward the domain, with infrastructure depending on domain abstractions (interfaces) - this is Dependency Inversion.

questions.text: RESTful APIs must use XML for data transfer.
questions.explanation: REST is format-agnostic. While JSON is the most common format today, REST APIs can use XML, JSON, plain text, or any other format. The key is proper use of HTTP methods and status codes.

questions.text: Power Automate can integrate with third-party services like Twitter and Salesforce.
questions.explanation: Power Automate has hundreds of connectors for both Microsoft and third-party services, including Twitter, Salesforce, Dropbox, Google services, and many more, enabling broad integration capabilities.

questions.text: Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS) automatically manages Kubernetes master nodes.
questions.explanation: AKS is a managed Kubernetes service where Azure handles the control plane (master nodes) including updates, patches, and high availability. Users only manage and pay for the agent (worker) nodes.

questions.text: The Open/Closed Principle states that classes should be open for modification and closed for extension.
questions.explanation: The Open/Closed Principle states the opposite: software entities should be open for extension but closed for modification. You should be able to add new functionality without changing existing code.

questions.text: In ASP.NET Core, middleware components are executed in the order they are added.
questions.explanation: Middleware components in ASP.NET Core form a pipeline and are executed in the order they're registered in the Configure method. The order matters significantly for proper request processing.

questions.text: Azure Service Bus supports both queues and topics/subscriptions.
questions.explanation: Azure Service Bus provides both queues (point-to-point communication) and topics with subscriptions (publish-subscribe pattern), offering flexible messaging patterns for different scenarios.

questions.text: SharePoint Search results are the same for all users regardless of permissions.
questions.explanation: SharePoint Search implements security trimming at the item level. Users only see search results for content they have permission to access, ensuring security is maintained in search results.

questions.text: Event-driven architecture always requires a message broker.
questions.explanation: While message brokers (like Service Bus or Event Grid) are common in event-driven architectures, events can also be handled directly through callbacks, delegates, or in-memory event buses for simpler scenarios.

questions.text: Azure Application Gateway can perform SSL/TLS termination.
questions.explanation: Azure Application Gateway supports SSL/TLS termination, offloading the decryption workload from backend servers. It also supports end-to-end SSL and can re-encrypt traffic to backend pools.

questions.text: A .NET solution architect should prioritize coupling over cohesion.
questions.explanation: This is incorrect. A well-designed architecture should always favor low coupling (components are independent) and high cohesion (components have a well-defined, focused purpose). This makes the system more maintainable, testable, and scalable.

questions.text: Container images should be built using minimal base images for security.
questions.explanation: Using minimal base images (like Alpine Linux or .NET's runtime-deps images) is a security best practice. It reduces the container's attack surface by excluding unnecessary tools and libraries, and it also results in smaller, faster image downloads.

questions.text: Unit tests should not access real databases.
questions.explanation: Unit tests should be fast and test a single unit of code in isolation. Accessing external dependencies like a database makes it an integration test, which is slower and more brittle. These dependencies should be mocked or stubbed out.

questions.text: Power Apps Canvas apps can only connect to Microsoft 365 services.
questions.explanation: Power Apps Canvas apps support a vast library of standard and premium connectors, allowing them to connect to hundreds of services, including SQL Server, Dataverse, Salesforce, Twitter, and many others, not just Microsoft 365.

questions.text: SharePoint Online supports full trust farm solutions.
questions.explanation: Full-trust farm solutions, which run server-side code in the SharePoint process, are strictly for on-premises deployments. SharePoint Online is a multi-tenant environment and does not allow this level of access. Modern development uses the SharePoint Framework (SPFx) and external APIs.

questions.text: Azure Service Bus is used for real-time streaming analytics.
questions.explanation: Azure Event Hubs is the service designed for high-throughput, real-time data ingestion and streaming analytics. Azure Service Bus is a brokered messaging service designed for reliable, enterprise-grade messaging with features like queues, topics, and dead-lettering.

questions.text: ASP.NET Core middleware executes in a pipeline sequentially.
questions.explanation: The ASP.NET Core request pipeline is composed of a sequence of middleware components. Each piece of middleware is executed in the order it was added to the pipeline and can choose to pass the request to the next component or short-circuit the pipeline by generating a response itself.

questions.text: Clean Architecture enforces separation of concerns through concentric layers.
questions.explanation: Clean Architecture, promoted by Robert C. Martin, organizes code into concentric layers (Entities, Use Cases, Interface Adapters, Frameworks & Drivers) with a strict dependency rule: source code dependencies can only point inwards. This creates a system that is independent of frameworks, UI, and databases.

questions.text: Entity Framework Core supports both LINQ and raw SQL queries.
questions.explanation: While LINQ is the primary method for querying, EF Core provides `FromSqlRaw` and `FromSqlInterpolated` methods to execute raw SQL queries for scenarios where LINQ is insufficient or less performant. This offers flexibility while still providing object materialization.

questions.text: SharePoint Search respects security trimming at the item level.
questions.explanation: Storing JWTs in local storage makes them accessible to any JavaScript running on the page, creating a significant Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vulnerability. Storing them in secure, HttpOnly cookies is a much safer alternative for web applications.
